THE NEWS LETTER'
VOL. XVI, NO. 28.

PLANS MATURING
Details of Senior Week Festivities Taking Form in Hands of Committee.
Weyforth, Valedictorian.

The work of the Senior Week
Committee has been chiefly directed
toward completing the program for
the Class Day exercises, which will
take place in McCoy Hall on Monday afternoon, June m. A special
committee consisting of Messrs.
H. Graham Dubois, Ellis Miller,
John K. Burgan and Lindsay
Rogers has been working in cooperation with the main committee
upon the literary features of the
occasion. The program, so far as
completed, will contain two addresses, an elaborate play written
for the occasion in verse, a dramatic sketch of a different character and a number of musical and
humorous features whose nature
the committee prefers not to divulge.
At a meeting of the class held
" for the purpose some time ago, Dr.
John C. French was unanimously
elected honorary president of the
class and invited to deliver the
opening or salutatory address. The
action was taken as a tribute to
Dr. French's personal popularity
and in recognition of his enthusiastic and helpful support of the
Senior Week movement. The valedictory address will be made by
Mr. William 0. Weyforth, who
was unanimously chosen for that
honor. The play is from the
skilled pen of,Mr. Dubois, whose
success as a poet and writer of
fiction is well known. Besides
being of real literary merit, it contains such an abundance of local
color and pointed references that it
is certain to be hugely enjoyed by
everyone. .
Although not all the exams are
over by Wednesday, June 5, the
seniors will have completed theirs
and be at leisure to enjoy the dean's
dinner, which will probably be'
given that night at the club.
The next day, when everybody's
exams are over, and even the
‘`grad" students are feeling kittenish, will come off one of the most
important events in Senior Week-the prom. Mr. Easter, who is managing the dance, anounced Friday
that tickets would be two dollars
and a half apiece, or fifty cents less
than they usually are. This, however, means that there .must: •be
every bit as many people there as
at the cotillon. The seniors have
started the ball rolling; but they
can't keep it rolling unless all the
fellows in the undergraduate body
give the movement their undivided
support.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 20, 1912.

• With the fellows in white trousers and the fairies flitting across the
"campus," Garden street, with its
lamp posts decorated with Japanese lanterns, ought to present a
sight unrivalled in the history of
the University.
The tickets for the boat ride on
Friday have been distributed among
the lower classes, and will be distributed among the alumni, graduate and medical students at an early
date this week. The stops which
the "Annapolis" will make have
not been decided upon, but it is
understood that a petition is being
gotten up in LeveripP: Hall to make
Flood's one of them.
Saturday 'a fterndon will see many
curious stunts at Homewood. Impromptu lacrosse and baseball
games have a prominent part on theprogram.
Saturday night witnesses a dinner
on "the shore," probably at Thompson's.
Sunday the seniors and their
friends will hear a baccalaureate
sermon ; letters have .been written
to many prominent clergymen, but,
as yet, they have not made any
final arrangements.
President Remsen's luncheon is
to be held On Monday, probably at
one o'clock.
• Though the committee has made
no definite plans for Monday night,
they can be relied upon not to
allow any anti-climax to mar the
geometrical progression of pleasure.
• Tuesday is to be Commencement Day, when a large attendance
of lusty-lunged undergraduates is
expected at the Academy. Many
of the fellows have offered to stir
up enthusiasm to make sure that
the revival of spirit will be a true
revival.
Tuesday night is the president's
reception, which delightful occasion
will be much more delightful this
year, after such a week of jollity,
camaraderie and good-fellowship.
Such a program makes sure that
no senior can leave college without
exclaiming: "Long live our alma
mater !" The day of disinterested
alumni is over.
1914 Hullabaloo Meets.

The Hullabaloo Board of 1914
was called together last week for
its first meeting by A. L. Hammond, the editor-in-chief. Matters
relating to the voting• of the Board,
methods of finance and other broad
topics were touched upon. Nothing of vital importance was decided,.because of the length of time
still remaining before the publication of the book. The next meeting is to be early next year.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

LEE ELECTED
-----

HOPKINS DOWNS ST. JOHN'S

Heaviest Vote in Years Causes Close
Contest for Places on the
Athletic Board.

Annapolitans Outplayed in Every Department of the Game—Pieper
Only Allows Two Hits.

The annual election of officers and
delegates to the Athletic Board was
held by the Athletic Association on
Wednesday. Freddie Lee was
elected president of the Association
for the coming year, after a close
contest with C. Leland Getz, the
other candidate.
Lee's election has been met with
by approval from all sides, as he
is considered a man most capable
for the position. His experience as
senior .delegate this year and as
. captain of the track team should
have given him all .the training
necessary to make a first-rate president. "Butts" Sutton was elected
vice-president and George Gillet
corresponding secretary of the
Board. Ben Tappan was elected
delegate froin the Medical School
and Eddie Hulburt was chosen t:.)
be representative from the graduate students. No election for alumni delegate was necessary, as there
was no one nominated to oppose
• "Father Bill" Schmeisser, whose
three years' term expired this year.
There are few other men who spend
so much time upon and take such
interest in Hopkins athletics as Bill
Schmeisser, and it is a matter of
congratulation for ourselves that he
was re-elected unanimously.
By a motion, passed at the beginning of the meeting, the constitution was amended so that there
will be from this time on three
representatives from the senior
class, two from the junior and one
from the sophomore, instead of
two from the senior and one each
from the junior and sophomore
classes.
According to the new system,
the senior delegates elei&ed were
Ernest J. Pieper, Julian D. Sears
and Embry H. Niles, all of whom
are members of 'varsity Jeams.
From the junior class Guy T. 0.
Hollyday and Pete Porter were
elected, and from the sophomores
Tommy Trokall.
The election, on the •whole, was
very closely contested in every
office and an unusually large vote
was cast.
The following is a detailed report
of the voting:
For President—Lee,81 ; Getz,.65.
For Vice-President—Sutton, 85 ;
Huck, 2.
For 'Corresponding Secretary—
Gillet, 8o; Brown, 36;.Catlin',.3i.
For Medical School Delegate—
Tappan, 61; -Horrax, 48; -Morton, 35.
(Conhnued on page 5, col. 3.)

Pieper's steady pitching and the
fine support accorded him by his
team mates enabled Hopkins to give
St. John's a sound drubbing last
Saturday at Homewood.
The
score was 7 to I. Although Tolson, the St. John's twirler, struck
out fifteen men, he gave seven
passes and the seven Hopkins hits
were made at times when hits meant
runs. Pieper was in fine form and
allowed only two hits. St. John's
lone tally was made by Hightman
in the second inning, when he
clouted one of Pieper's shoots to
deep left field for a home run.
Hopkins started in to win the
game from the very beginning.
Tolson struck out Porter, the first
Hopkins batter, but then walked
Ober, Williams and Hobbs, filling
the bases. Ober and •Williams
crossed the plate on Pieper's single
to right field. Hobbs tallied in the
third in
when Thompson
missed a single to right field, which
rolled under the fence.
W. Smith beat out a bunt in the
sixth session and stole second, he
scored on Ober's single to left field.
Hopkins tallied again in the seventh
inning and made its last run in the
eighth; period.
The Hopkins outfielders • played
fine ball. They have played phenommally all season, and are without a doubt the best college trio
in the State. Hopkins is the only
Maryland nine which has a clean
slate for the Maryland intercollegiate championship. Although Hopkins has only played Western
Taryland, Maryland Agricultural
College and St. John's, it disposed
of each of these in short order.
St. John's had about as clear a title
to the Maryland championship as
any of the State colleges and so
Hopkins' victory ought to undoubtedly make the Black and Blue nine
the Maryland intercollegiate baseball champions.

The movement in the sophomore
and junior classes to revive old
traditions and to get out a Hullabaloo, received new impetus last Saturday night from the proceeds of
a concert and dance. The Musical
Clubs surprised some of its oldest
members by having several new
selections on the program.
The "Ode," likewise "Katy Did,"
received their quota of applause,
though not until. Dr. Uhlig sang
some tenor solos, 'did the real enthusiasm manifest itself. T h e
quartette, selected, composed of
Messrs. Fulton, Geisel, Gillet, Everton a n d Tappan, as always, .
charmed the audience. Jacobs and
Schneeberger played a mandolin
duet, which started off along classic
lines (Lustspiel overture), but
ended up in "Sweetheart If You
Talk in Your Sleep."
• "The Cock of the Barnyard,"
dedicated to the Glee Club by M r.
R. L. Haslup, was ably rendered,
and much enlivened by the mimicing- of "Gabe" Todes. "Everybody's Doing It," by the Instrumental Club, set the stands swaying, as a sort of Preamble to the
Glee Club's "Roars" for the Black
and Blue.
The dance deserves notice of
equal length. When Weber and
Fields quit playing selections from
the operas and come down to
"Alexander's," the rag-time couples
set off at a killing pace.
Contrary to the expectations of
some misanthropes, the moderate
price Of fifty cents did not depopulate Farson's. River View or Electric Park. A more elite crowd has
seldom been assembled in Baltimore.
Among those present were:

THE NEWS-LETTER, MAY

5

20, 1912.

LACROSSE SEASON REVIEWED

THE OUTDOOR TRACK SEASON

1912 TO HAVE A CLASS BOOK

Hopkins Wins Four Games and Loses
Three; Shoots 26 Goals to
Opponents' 29.

Two Meets Won; Two Lost —South
Atlantic Intercollegiate Athletic
Association Championship.

Pamphlet "Hullabaloo" Made Possible
By Generous Gift From News-Letter.
Will Appear After Exams.

Although it can hardly be said
that the lacrosse season this year
was grandly and gloriously successful, nevertheless, it is interesting to
look at some of the results in a way
different from the ordinary newspaper accounts.
The team played seven games, of
Which it lost three—to Carlisle,
Swarthmore and Lehigh—tied two,
With alumni and Cornell, and won
two, from Harvard and Stevens.
Although we won from Harvard by
but one point, nevertheless, up to
the time of the Lehigh game, we
had scored more goals than our
opponents, so close was the score
of the games which we lost.
A summary of the scores is:
March 30—Hopkins, 2; Alumni, 2.
April 6—Hopkins, 2; Cornell, 2.
April 13—Hopkins,5 ; Harvard,4.
April 20—Hopkins, 4; Carlisle, 8.
April 27—Hopkins,8; Stevens, o.
May 4—Hopkins, 2; Swarthmore, 4.
May i 1—Hopkins, 3; Lehigh, 9.
-Total—Hopkins,. 26; opponents,
29.
In spite of the large number of
defeats, it is pleasing to knor that
the team did not die down or quit
in the second half, even when the
score was hopelessly against us,
for in every game but two we
scored the last goal. The two were
Lehigh and 'Harvard, in one of
which we had scored more in the
second half than we did in the
first, and the other of which was
a victory.
Captain Bill Gail scored the
greatest number of goals, twelve in
all; he also holds the record for
goals in a single game, which is
four, made against Stevens. Jimmy
Easter comes next with seven
goals scored; Troxell and Voshell
have two each; and Everton, Hollyday and Benedict each shot one.
Altogether twenty men played in
the games this year, of whom ten
played in every game. They are:
Schmeisser, Niles, Huck, Ellicott,
Benedict, Everton, Voshell, Paulus,
Gail and Easter. The others are:
Sutton, 6; Hollyday, 5; Makel, 5 ;
Troxell, 5; Sears, 4; Angell, 3;
Price, i ; Richardson, i ; Gillet, I,
and La Motte, I.
It was calculated earlier in the
season that during the Indian game
.1-Iollyday, playing centre, ran more
than five miles. It has now been
calculated at what rate goals were
shot. The season consisted of 440
minutes (7 hours and 20 minutes
playing time). This gives an average interval between goals for the
'varsity of 17 minutes, and for
their opponents 15.2 minutes. The
average time between -oals for both
sides- was,8 minutes.

The establishment of the South
Atlantic Intercollegiate Athletic
Association through the efforts of
Joseph T. England, its president
and Hopkins representative, and the
subsequent victory for the 'varsity
track team in the first annual meet of
the Association stand • out prominently in a review of the past season. Such an association had been
talked of and planned by the University for several years, and now
that it is on its feet, with the first
championship won, track athletics
at Hopkins will continue to grow
better. The score of the meet,
which was held at Homewood, was
as follows: Hopkins, 48y); North
Carolina, 28; A. & M., 24; V. P. I.,
232; W. & L., 15 ; Georgetown,
13, and Richmond College, o. The
feature of the meet was the victory
of the 'varsity relay team (Uhler,
Stiebel, Fulton and Hunter) over
the Georgetown and the Washington and Lee teams. The old Hopkins record of 1901 was equalled;
time, 3.33.4.
The Swarthmore meet (April
27) resulted in a walkover; score,
67-37. The times and distances
made were not good, however, due
to the early date of the meet.
The Naval Academy beat the
'varsity the following. Saturday,
68Y3 points to 38TA. Dignan broke
the Navy and Hopkins shot-put
records with a throw of 43 feet 3
inches. Wagner equalled the 'varsity record of io seconds for the
mo-yard dash and Dalton for the
Navy beat Horrax in the high
hurdles and established a Navy
/
5 seconds for the
record of 153
event. Horrax holds the same record at Hopkins.
Last Saturday, Virginia won the
annual dual meet at Charlottesville,
49-39. The score varied throughout—a few points in favor of Hopkins, then a few points in favor of
Virginia — until the end. The
features of the meet was Cooke's
wonderful running in the mile and
half-mile and Wagner's in the ioo
and 220-yard dashes. Wagner did
the wo in io seconds for the second time this season. He and
fi Pennsylvania man are the only
ones to run the century so far this
season in io seconds.
Individual scores follow,:
Horrax, 652 points; Wagner,
40; Dignan, 27; Bridgman, 16;
/
3 ; Fulton, 9; Catlin,
Tappan, i41
7; Reeside, 6; Hunter, 5; Baldwin,
2, and Wells, i.

THE NEWS-LETTER, MAY 20, 1912..
CHANCE FOR COLLEGE CRITICS

WHAT 1912 WILL DO

Two Prizes Offered for Best Plan for
the Social Organization of
a University.

Four Lawyers, Four Doctors, Seven
Chemists and One Preacher in this
Year's Graduating Class.

.1 recent issue of the cw York
Times contained the announcement
of an offer of two prizes, $150 and
$100 for the best essay giving a
constructive plan for the social organization of a university or a college. The first prize is open to
undergraduates, while the second is
limited to graduates.
The donor of the prizes is Owen
Johnson, • author of "Stover at
Yale," which has aroused so much
discussion because of its frank
criticisms of conditions in American
colleges and universities today.
In a communication to the Times
announcing his offer Mr. Johnson
says:

A canvass of the intentions of
the class of 1912 shows interesting
results. Twenty-four of the thirtysix men graduating this year will
pursue some sort of advance study.
All but seven of these will come
back to Hopkins for their courses.
What 1912 will do:
Medical School—Applebaum, M.
H. Coblentz, Grempler, Sutton.
Business—Cole (with father in,
Richmond), Dickey (with father in
wool business), Schmeisser, Stewart, Thomas (with father).
Undecided—Belt, Price, Rogers.
Chemistry—J. E. L. Holmes, M.
Hopkins, Lee, Lloyd, Paulus, E. C.
White, E. Miller.
Other graduate work—Benedict
(says he's looking for an heiress),
Brown (sanskrit a n d Greek,)
Burgan (electricity), Dubois (English?), Gorton (physics).
Law—J. J. Corner (Harvard),
Rosenfeld (UniversitV of Maryland, also economics here), Todes
( University of Maryland, also
business), Weyforth (University
of Maryland; economics here?).
Engineering—Carroll (?), Easter (Boston Tech), Fulton, Gail
(Boston Tech).
Landscape gardening — Buckler
( Harvard).
Hopkins Y. M. C. A. secretary—
Wagner (in place of Mr. Holmes).
Ministry—Harrison.
Real estate and insurance —
Hatch.
-"Society of the Claw" Started.
A good many of the members of
the class of 1894, of Princeton,
have pledged themselves to get tog-ether for at least five successive reunions, to be held every June. The
signing of the pledge is the only
requisite for admission into the
"Society of the Claw.- The idea
is simply to bind members of the
class into the form of a society to
return each year to Princeton.
Those who have done some great
service or reflected honor on their
alma mater are eligible for honorary membership in the society.
Regular members wear a silvermounted claw on their watch chains
-41-the claw coming, supposedly,
from the proverbial defender of the
Orange and the Black. Honorary
members are presented with goldmounted claws, on which are engraved the reason for the mem:,
ber being admitted to the society.
There ain't no dues to this society!!
We believe it's the only such in existence.

"There will be not the slightest limitation, to the nature of the plan submitted,
except of its possible effectiveness in the
safeguarding of education and democracy.
"I hope that strong papers may be submitte(l in behalf of all existing systems
( with suggested imnrovements in the
matter of detail), and that e,ually, there
may be plans submitted for an entirely
different system of division, as well as
Plans that would argue for no systems
at all.
"The manuscripts should be submitted
in typewritten form and signed by a
nom de guerre, the real name being inclosed in a separate envelope. In any
case where, for obvious reasons, a contributor does not desire to reveal his
identity, his preference will be considered, even in the event of his winning
the prize.
"The competition will close Tune 2,
and the announcement of .the winners
Will be made in the Sunday Times of
June 9.
"I am glad to announce that the Hon.
Otto T. Bonnard, Mr. Norman Hapgood,
and Prof. Henry Fairfield Osborn have
generously contributed their services and
Will act as a jury.
"From time to time. as the answers
warrant it, the Times will publish them
during the progress of the competition.

OWEN JOHNSON."
New Record Accepted.

Dignan's new record of 43 feet,
3 inches in the shot-put made in
the Navy dual meet two weeks ago
was officially accepted as a Hopkins
record by the Board of Directors
of the Hopkins General Athletic
Association last Monday night.
Wagner was also credited with having equaled the Hopkins record of
10 seconds flat in the Too-yard dash.
The Hopkins one-mile outdoor relay record of 3 minutes, 33-Y5 seconds, made by England, Hoffman,
Whitman, and Riggs, in 1901, was
equaled by the Hopkins quartet in
the championship relay race held in
connection with the South Atlantic
Intercollegiate track and field meet.

TENNIS TOURNAMENT ON

A TEMPTING OPPORTUNITY

THE

NEWS-LET-1'ER:

We desire to call your attention
to an education tour of France,
which has been organized for the
coming summer, under the auspices
of the French Society of Columbia
University. The tour is to be conducted entirely for educational purposes, and is open to any students
desiring to go. It will enable a student to see France under the best
possible circumstances, in the most
agreeable manner, with pleasant
companions, and in the least expensive way.
The trip will not be a commercial
enterprise, and will be entirely informal. The expenses have been reduced to absolute minimum cost,
and sight-seeing will be on a very
liberal scale. The total cost of the
tour will be $375.
The journey will take about
eighty days, including the voyage.
The start for France will be made
on June 22d, 1912, and return
around September 9th. Landing at
Havre, the party will travel through
Normandy. Brittany, the chateaux
country, Perigord, the Pyrenees,
Gascogne, Auvergne, Berry, Savoy,
Provence, the Alps, and, lastly,
Paris and its environs.
Exceptional advantages are offered by this tour in the line of studying architecture and art in general,
literature and historical monuments,
as permission has been granted to
visit places which are otherwise
closed to public or private tours.
The best accommodations will be
provided for all, and for the price
mentioned 11 expenses are paid.
This is a splendid opportunity for
any student who is interested in
France or things French, and a fine
chance for a student who wishes to
pass an agreeable summer, and
would like to become acquainted
with France and the language itself.
Anyone desiring further and illustrated information should address
French Society Tour, Columbia
University, and appointments for
interview will be arranged.
Very truly yours,
ALEXANDRE BRUNO,
President.

THE NEWS LETTER'
VOL. XVI, NO. 28.

PLANS MATURING
Details of Senior Week Festivities Taking Form in Hands of Committee.
Weyforth, Valedictorian.

The work of the Senior Week
Committee has been chiefly directed
toward completing the program for
the Class Day exercises, which will
take place in McCoy Hall on Monday afternoon, June m. A special
committee consisting of Messrs.
H. Graham Dubois, Ellis Miller,
John K. Burgan and Lindsay
Rogers has been working in cooperation with the main committee
upon the literary features of the
occasion. The program, so far as
completed, will contain two addresses, an elaborate play written
for the occasion in verse, a dramatic sketch of a different character and a number of musical and
humorous features whose nature
the committee prefers not to divulge.
At a meeting of the class held
" for the purpose some time ago, Dr.
John C. French was unanimously
elected honorary president of the
class and invited to deliver the
opening or salutatory address. The
action was taken as a tribute to
Dr. French's personal popularity
and in recognition of his enthusiastic and helpful support of the
Senior Week movement. The valedictory address will be made by
Mr. William 0. Weyforth, who
was unanimously chosen for that
honor. The play is from the
skilled pen of,Mr. Dubois, whose
success as a poet and writer of
fiction is well known. Besides
being of real literary merit, it contains such an abundance of local
color and pointed references that it
is certain to be hugely enjoyed by
everyone. .
Although not all the exams are
over by Wednesday, June 5, the
seniors will have completed theirs
and be at leisure to enjoy the dean's
dinner, which will probably be'
given that night at the club.
The next day, when everybody's
exams are over, and even the
‘`grad" students are feeling kittenish, will come off one of the most
important events in Senior Week-the prom. Mr. Easter, who is managing the dance, anounced Friday
that tickets would be two dollars
and a half apiece, or fifty cents less
than they usually are. This, however, means that there .must: •be
every bit as many people there as
at the cotillon. The seniors have
started the ball rolling; but they
can't keep it rolling unless all the
fellows in the undergraduate body
give the movement their undivided
support.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 20, 1912.

• With the fellows in white trousers and the fairies flitting across the
"campus," Garden street, with its
lamp posts decorated with Japanese lanterns, ought to present a
sight unrivalled in the history of
the University.
The tickets for the boat ride on
Friday have been distributed among
the lower classes, and will be distributed among the alumni, graduate and medical students at an early
date this week. The stops which
the "Annapolis" will make have
not been decided upon, but it is
understood that a petition is being
gotten up in LeveripP: Hall to make
Flood's one of them.
Saturday 'a fterndon will see many
curious stunts at Homewood. Impromptu lacrosse and baseball
games have a prominent part on theprogram.
Saturday night witnesses a dinner
on "the shore," probably at Thompson's.
Sunday the seniors and their
friends will hear a baccalaureate
sermon ; letters have .been written
to many prominent clergymen, but,
as yet, they have not made any
final arrangements.
President Remsen's luncheon is
to be held On Monday, probably at
one o'clock.
• Though the committee has made
no definite plans for Monday night,
they can be relied upon not to
allow any anti-climax to mar the
geometrical progression of pleasure.
• Tuesday is to be Commencement Day, when a large attendance
of lusty-lunged undergraduates is
expected at the Academy. Many
of the fellows have offered to stir
up enthusiasm to make sure that
the revival of spirit will be a true
revival.
Tuesday night is the president's
reception, which delightful occasion
will be much more delightful this
year, after such a week of jollity,
camaraderie and good-fellowship.
Such a program makes sure that
no senior can leave college without
exclaiming: "Long live our alma
mater !" The day of disinterested
alumni is over.
1914 Hullabaloo Meets.

The Hullabaloo Board of 1914
was called together last week for
its first meeting by A. L. Hammond, the editor-in-chief. Matters
relating to the voting• of the Board,
methods of finance and other broad
topics were touched upon. Nothing of vital importance was decided,.because of the length of time
still remaining before the publication of the book. The next meeting is to be early next year.

LEE ELECTED
-----

HOPKINS DOWNS ST. JOHN'S

Heaviest Vote in Years Causes Close
Contest for Places on the
Athletic Board.

Annapolitans Outplayed in Every Department of the Game—Pieper
Only Allows Two Hits.

The annual election of officers and
delegates to the Athletic Board was
held by the Athletic Association on
Wednesday. Freddie Lee was
elected president of the Association
for the coming year, after a close
contest with C. Leland Getz, the
other candidate.
Lee's election has been met with
by approval from all sides, as he
is considered a man most capable
for the position. His experience as
senior .delegate this year and as
. captain of the track team should
have given him all .the training
necessary to make a first-rate president. "Butts" Sutton was elected
vice-president and George Gillet
corresponding secretary of the
Board. Ben Tappan was elected
delegate froin the Medical School
and Eddie Hulburt was chosen t:.)
be representative from the graduate students. No election for alumni delegate was necessary, as there
was no one nominated to oppose
• "Father Bill" Schmeisser, whose
three years' term expired this year.
There are few other men who spend
so much time upon and take such
interest in Hopkins athletics as Bill
Schmeisser, and it is a matter of
congratulation for ourselves that he
was re-elected unanimously.
By a motion, passed at the beginning of the meeting, the constitution was amended so that there
will be from this time on three
representatives from the senior
class, two from the junior and one
from the sophomore, instead of
two from the senior and one each
from the junior and sophomore
classes.
According to the new system,
the senior delegates elei&ed were
Ernest J. Pieper, Julian D. Sears
and Embry H. Niles, all of whom
are members of 'varsity Jeams.
From the junior class Guy T. 0.
Hollyday and Pete Porter were
elected, and from the sophomores
Tommy Trokall.
The election, on the •whole, was
very closely contested in every
office and an unusually large vote
was cast.
The following is a detailed report
of the voting:
For President—Lee,81 ; Getz,.65.
For Vice-President—Sutton, 85 ;
Huck, 2.
For 'Corresponding Secretary—
Gillet, 8o; Brown, 36;.Catlin',.3i.
For Medical School Delegate—
Tappan, 61; -Horrax, 48; -Morton, 35.
(Conhnued on page 5, col. 3.)

Pieper's steady pitching and the
fine support accorded him by his
team mates enabled Hopkins to give
St. John's a sound drubbing last
Saturday at Homewood.
The
score was 7 to I. Although Tolson, the St. John's twirler, struck
out fifteen men, he gave seven
passes and the seven Hopkins hits
were made at times when hits meant
runs. Pieper was in fine form and
allowed only two hits. St. John's
lone tally was made by Hightman
in the second inning, when he
clouted one of Pieper's shoots to
deep left field for a home run.
Hopkins started in to win the
game from the very beginning.
Tolson struck out Porter, the first
Hopkins batter, but then walked
Ober, Williams and Hobbs, filling
the bases. Ober and •Williams
crossed the plate on Pieper's single
to right field. Hobbs tallied in the
third in
when Thompson
missed a single to right field, which
rolled under the fence.
W. Smith beat out a bunt in the
sixth session and stole second, he
scored on Ober's single to left field.
Hopkins tallied again in the seventh
inning and made its last run in the
eighth; period.
The Hopkins outfielders • played
fine ball. They have played phenommally all season, and are without a doubt the best college trio
in the State. Hopkins is the only
Maryland nine which has a clean
slate for the Maryland intercollegiate championship. Although Hopkins has only played Western
Taryland, Maryland Agricultural
College and St. John's, it disposed
of each of these in short order.
St. John's had about as clear a title
to the Maryland championship as
any of the State colleges and so
Hopkins' victory ought to undoubtedly make the Black and Blue nine
the Maryland intercollegiate baseball champions.

The movement in the sophomore
and junior classes to revive old
traditions and to get out a Hullabaloo, received new impetus last Saturday night from the proceeds of
a concert and dance. The Musical
Clubs surprised some of its oldest
members by having several new
selections on the program.
The "Ode," likewise "Katy Did,"
received their quota of applause,
though not until. Dr. Uhlig sang
some tenor solos, 'did the real enthusiasm manifest itself. T h e
quartette, selected, composed of
Messrs. Fulton, Geisel, Gillet, Everton a n d Tappan, as always, .
charmed the audience. Jacobs and
Schneeberger played a mandolin
duet, which started off along classic
lines (Lustspiel overture), but
ended up in "Sweetheart If You
Talk in Your Sleep."
• "The Cock of the Barnyard,"
dedicated to the Glee Club by M r.
R. L. Haslup, was ably rendered,
and much enlivened by the mimicing- of "Gabe" Todes. "Everybody's Doing It," by the Instrumental Club, set the stands swaying, as a sort of Preamble to the
Glee Club's "Roars" for the Black
and Blue.
The dance deserves notice of
equal length. When Weber and
Fields quit playing selections from
the operas and come down to
"Alexander's," the rag-time couples
set off at a killing pace.
Contrary to the expectations of

LACROSSE SEASON REVIEWED

THE OUTDOOR TRACK SEASON

1912 TO HAVE A CLASS BOOK

Hopkins Wins Four Games and Loses
Three; Shoots 26 Goals to
Opponents' 29.

Two Meets Won; Two Lost —South
Atlantic Intercollegiate Athletic
Association Championship.

Pamphlet "Hullabaloo" Made Possible
By Generous Gift From News-Letter.
Will Appear After Exams.

Although it can hardly be said
that the lacrosse season this year
was grandly and gloriously successful, nevertheless, it is interesting to
look at some of the results in a way
different from the ordinary newspaper accounts.
The team played seven games, of
Which it lost three—to Carlisle,
Swarthmore and Lehigh—tied two,
With alumni and Cornell, and won
two, from Harvard and Stevens.
Although we won from Harvard by
but one point, nevertheless, up to
the time of the Lehigh game, we
had scored more goals than our
opponents, so close was the score
of the games which we lost.
A summary of the scores is:
March 30—Hopkins, 2; Alumni, 2.
April 6—Hopkins, 2; Cornell, 2.
April 13—Hopkins,5 ; Harvard,4.
April 20—Hopkins, 4; Carlisle, 8.
April 27—Hopkins,8; Stevens, o.
May 4—Hopkins, 2; Swarthmore, 4.
May i 1—Hopkins, 3; Lehigh, 9.
-Total—Hopkins,. 26; opponents,
29.
In spite of the large number of
defeats, it is pleasing to knor that
the team did not die down or quit
in the second half, even when the
score was hopelessly against us,
for in every game but two we
scored the last goal. The two were
Lehigh and 'Harvard, in one of
which we had scored more in the
second half than we did in the
first, and the other of which was
a victory.
Captain Bill Gail scored the
greatest number of goals, twelve in
all; he also holds the record for
goals in a single game, which is
four, made against Stevens. Jimmy
Easter comes next with seven
goals scored; Troxell and Voshell
have two each; and Everton, Hollyday and Benedict each shot one.
Altogether twenty men played in
the games this year, of whom ten
played in every game. They are:
Schmeisser, Niles, Huck, Ellicott,
Benedict, Everton, Voshell, Paulus,
Gail and Easter. The others are:
Sutton, 6; Hollyday, 5; Makel, 5 ;
Troxell, 5; Sears, 4; Angell, 3;
Price, i ; Richardson, i ; Gillet, I,
and La Motte, I.
It was calculated earlier in the
season that during the Indian game
.1-Iollyday, playing centre, ran more
than five miles. It has now been
calculated at what rate goals were
shot. The season consisted of 440
minutes (7 hours and 20 minutes
playing time). This gives an average interval between goals for the
'varsity of 17 minutes, and for
their opponents 15.2 minutes. The
average time between -oals for both
sides- was,8 minutes.

The establishment of the South
Atlantic Intercollegiate Athletic
Association through the efforts of
Joseph T. England, its president
and Hopkins representative, and the
subsequent victory for the 'varsity
track team in the first annual meet of
the Association stand • out prominently in a review of the past season. Such an association had been
talked of and planned by the University for several years, and now
that it is on its feet, with the first
championship won, track athletics
at Hopkins will continue to grow
better. The score of the meet,
which was held at Homewood, was
as follows: Hopkins, 48y); North
Carolina, 28; A. & M., 24; V. P. I.,
232; W. & L., 15 ; Georgetown,
13, and Richmond College, o. The
feature of the meet was the victory
of the 'varsity relay team (Uhler,
Stiebel, Fulton and Hunter) over
the Georgetown and the Washington and Lee teams. The old Hopkins record of 1901 was equalled;
time, 3.33.4.
The Swarthmore meet (April
27) resulted in a walkover; score,
67-37. The times and distances
made were not good, however, due
to the early date of the meet.
The Naval Academy beat the
'varsity the following. Saturday,
68Y3 points to 38TA. Dignan broke
the Navy and Hopkins shot-put
records with a throw of 43 feet 3
inches. Wagner equalled the 'varsity record of io seconds for the
mo-yard dash and Dalton for the
Navy beat Horrax in the high
hurdles and established a Navy
/
5 seconds for the
record of 153
event. Horrax holds the same record at Hopkins.
Last Saturday, Virginia won the
annual dual meet at Charlottesville,
49-39. The score varied throughout—a few points in favor of Hopkins, then a few points in favor of
Virginia — until the end. The
features of the meet was Cooke's
wonderful running in the mile and
half-mile and Wagner's in the ioo
and 220-yard dashes. Wagner did
the wo in io seconds for the second time this season. He and
fi Pennsylvania man are the only
ones to run the century so far this
season in io seconds.
Individual scores follow,:
Horrax, 652 points; Wagner,
40; Dignan, 27; Bridgman, 16;
/
3 ; Fulton, 9; Catlin,
Tappan, i41
7; Reeside, 6; Hunter, 5; Baldwin,
2, and Wells, i.

THE NEWS-LETTER, MAY 20, 1912..
CHANCE FOR COLLEGE CRITICS

WHAT 1912 WILL DO

Two Prizes Offered for Best Plan for
the Social Organization of
a University.

Four Lawyers, Four Doctors, Seven
Chemists and One Preacher in this
Year's Graduating Class.

.1 recent issue of the cw York
Times contained the announcement
of an offer of two prizes, $150 and
$100 for the best essay giving a
constructive plan for the social organization of a university or a college. The first prize is open to
undergraduates, while the second is
limited to graduates.
The donor of the prizes is Owen
Johnson, • author of "Stover at
Yale," which has aroused so much
discussion because of its frank
criticisms of conditions in American
colleges and universities today.
In a communication to the Times
announcing his offer Mr. Johnson
says:

A canvass of the intentions of
the class of 1912 shows interesting
results. Twenty-four of the thirtysix men graduating this year will
pursue some sort of advance study.
All but seven of these will come
back to Hopkins for their courses.
What 1912 will do:
Medical School—Applebaum, M.
H. Coblentz, Grempler, Sutton.
Business—Cole (with father in,
Richmond), Dickey (with father in
wool business), Schmeisser, Stewart, Thomas (with father).
Undecided—Belt, Price, Rogers.
Chemistry—J. E. L. Holmes, M.
Hopkins, Lee, Lloyd, Paulus, E. C.
White, E. Miller.
Other graduate work—Benedict
(says he's looking for an heiress),
Brown (sanskrit a n d Greek,)
Burgan (electricity), Dubois (English?), Gorton (physics).
Law—J. J. Corner (Harvard),
Rosenfeld (UniversitV of Maryland, also economics here), Todes
( University of Maryland, also
business), Weyforth (University
of Maryland; economics here?).
Engineering—Carroll (?), Easter (Boston Tech), Fulton, Gail
(Boston Tech).
Landscape gardening — Buckler
( Harvard).
Hopkins Y. M. C. A. secretary—
Wagner (in place of Mr. Holmes).
Ministry—Harrison.
Real estate and insurance —
Hatch.
-"Society of the Claw" Started.
A good many of the members of
the class of 1894, of Princeton,
have pledged themselves to get tog-ether for at least five successive reunions, to be held every June. The
signing of the pledge is the only
requisite for admission into the
"Society of the Claw.- The idea
is simply to bind members of the
class into the form of a society to
return each year to Princeton.
Those who have done some great
service or reflected honor on their
alma mater are eligible for honorary membership in the society.
Regular members wear a silvermounted claw on their watch chains
-41-the claw coming, supposedly,
from the proverbial defender of the
Orange and the Black. Honorary
members are presented with goldmounted claws, on which are engraved the reason for the mem:,
ber being admitted to the society.
There ain't no dues to this society!!
We believe it's the only such in existence.

"There will be not the slightest limitation, to the nature of the plan submitted,
except of its possible effectiveness in the
safeguarding of education and democracy.
"I hope that strong papers may be submitte(l in behalf of all existing systems
( with suggested imnrovements in the
matter of detail), and that e,ually, there
may be plans submitted for an entirely
different system of division, as well as
Plans that would argue for no systems
at all.
"The manuscripts should be submitted
in typewritten form and signed by a
nom de guerre, the real name being inclosed in a separate envelope. In any
case where, for obvious reasons, a contributor does not desire to reveal his
identity, his preference will be considered, even in the event of his winning
the prize.
"The competition will close Tune 2,
and the announcement of .the winners
Will be made in the Sunday Times of
June 9.
"I am glad to announce that the Hon.
Otto T. Bonnard, Mr. Norman Hapgood,
and Prof. Henry Fairfield Osborn have
generously contributed their services and
Will act as a jury.
"From time to time. as the answers
warrant it, the Times will publish them
during the progress of the competition.

OWEN JOHNSON."
New Record Accepted.

Dignan's new record of 43 feet,
3 inches in the shot-put made in
the Navy dual meet two weeks ago
was officially accepted as a Hopkins
record by the Board of Directors
of the Hopkins General Athletic
Association last Monday night.
Wagner was also credited with having equaled the Hopkins record of
10 seconds flat in the Too-yard dash.
The Hopkins one-mile outdoor relay record of 3 minutes, 33-Y5 seconds, made by England, Hoffman,
Whitman, and Riggs, in 1901, was
equaled by the Hopkins quartet in
the championship relay race held in
connection with the South Atlantic
Intercollegiate track and field meet.

of France.

TEXT BOOKS
in Stock at all times.

TENNIS TOURNAMENT ON

A TEMPTING OPPORTUNITY

THE

NEWS-LET-1'ER:

We desire to call your attention
to an education tour of France,
which has been organized for the
coming summer, under the auspices
of the French Society of Columbia
University. The tour is to be conducted entirely for educational purposes, and is open to any students
desiring to go. It will enable a student to see France under the best
possible circumstances, in the most
agreeable manner, with pleasant
companions, and in the least expensive way.
The trip will not be a commercial
enterprise, and will be entirely informal. The expenses have been reduced to absolute minimum cost,
and sight-seeing will be on a very
liberal scale. The total cost of the
tour will be $375.
The journey will take about
eighty days, including the voyage.
The start for France will be made
on June 22d, 1912, and return
around September 9th. Landing at
Havre, the party will travel through
Normandy. Brittany, the chateaux
country, Perigord, the Pyrenees,
Gascogne, Auvergne, Berry, Savoy,
Provence, the Alps, and, lastly,
Paris and its environs.
Exceptional advantages are offered by this tour in the line of studying architecture and art in general,
literature and historical monuments,
as permission has been granted to
visit places which are otherwise
closed to public or private tours.
The best accommodations will be
provided for all, and for the price
mentioned 11 expenses are paid.
This is a splendid opportunity for
any student who is interested in
France or things French, and a fine
chance for a student who wishes to
pass an agreeable summer, and
would like to become acquainted
with France and the language itself.
Anyone desiring further and illustrated information should address
French Society Tour, Columbia
University, and appointments for
interview will be arranged.
Very truly yours,
ALEXANDRE BRUNO,
President.
